Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 10:04PM Anne1962 wrote: ScariedCat, You sound a lot like me. We are even about the same age, and I also have zero family history of BC. When I first found out that I would need a biopsy for microcalcs I had trouble sleeping and eating, too. My results came back as atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH). Although ALH is a B9 finding it does put me at a higher risk for BC. I hope you get your results soon and that they are B9.  Wishing you luck, Anne1962

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2010 11:56AM Anne1962 wrote: Thanks, Leaf. Yes, the uncertainty is a pain. I guess I'm just getting a little more anxious now that my follow-up is getting closer. It is the "what-if" of it all that keeps me a little on edge.
Posts.Title: atypical lobular hyperplasia-tamoxifen Myshell vmudrow

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 12:52AM Anne1962 wrote: I was through menopause at the age of 37. It just happened. All kinds of testing was done to see why it happened at such a young age, but nothing showed up out of the ordinary. I also have osteoperosis and was put on HRT for many years to help with the menopause symptoms as well as bone density. After being diagnosed with ALH, I took myself off the HRT. HRT kind of messes a person up. I did not like being on it, but was told to stick with it. I don't believe the benefits outweighed the risks in my case and that is why I quit taking it. Who knows what will happen to me after being on it for so long. I am in the wait and see what happens next mode for now. Anne
Posts.Title: HRT causing breast cancer JPRacket45 marklee99

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2010 12:14PM Anne1962 wrote: Sweetie, I can see by your personal history why ALH is cause for serious concern; especially since that was the only thing that showed up on MRI. This is what concerns me, also. I didn't have an MRI or further surgery to rule anything else out, so it does make me wonder if there is anything else in there that didn't show up. I can only hope that if there is anything hiding in there that it will show up on my next mammo. Thank you for letting others know that even if the risk is low, it can still happen.  Anne
Posts.Title: atypical lobular hyperplasia-tamoxifen Myshell vmudrow

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 02:10AM Anne1962 wrote: Hi farmerlucydaisy, My ALH was discovered when I was 48. I am now almost 50. It was discovered on a routine mammogram. Currently, I'm not really doing anything. My BS said I was high risk, but now she says I'm not. My husband and sisters are urging me to get a second opinion. I am going to push for an MRI (I have very dense breasts) in a few months. My BS is not a fan of MRI; too many false positives. I didn't even have an excisional biopsy, although the radiologist suggested one. Keep me posted. There aren't a lot of us on here with ALH, but hopefully they will be along soon. Take Care, Anne1962
